text: Leucopogon pendulus is a shrub in the family Ericaceae. It is native to Western Australia. ==Description== Leucopogon pendulus is an erect shrub which grows to heights of from 0.1 m to 1.5 m. The white flowers may be seen from March to October in its native habitat. Leucopogon pendulus - Flickr - Kevin Thiele.jpg Leucopogon pendulus - 48480047251.jpg ==Distribution and habitat== It is found in the IBRA Regions of: Avon Wheatbelt, Esperance Plains, Jarrah Forest, Mallee, Swan Coastal Plain, and Warren, on sandy and gravelly soils, on seasonally wet flats, plains, outcrops and low ridges. ==Taxonomy== It was first described in 1810 by Robert Brown. The specific epithet, pendulus, is an adjective derived from the Latin verb, pendere ("to hang") and describes the plant as having hanging (pendulous) flowers. ==References== pendulus Category:Ericales of Australia Category:Eudicots of Western Australia Category:Plants described in 1810 Category:Taxa named by Robert Brown (botanist, born 1773)
